pr_title: Add info on each HTTP client to HTTP stats

timeline.message: add stats for each HTTP client
version-aware serialization, record address on first request instead of socket accept

timeline.bodyText: Should this use threadPool.relativeTimeInMillis() to ensure that it can't go backwards?
timeline.author: dakrone

replies.bodyText: @dakrone, thanks for reviewing this. I'm going to go through your comments and try to address them. With regard to this comment, the time values (e.g., open time, closed time, last request time) are all meant to be absolute. The only place a duration is calculated is here in the pruneClientStats method where any channels closed for longer than 5 minutes are pruned. I can add a separate nanosecond counter for the closed time if you think it's important that the pruning interval not be affected by time changes.
replies.author: danhermann

replies.bodyText: okay, since they're absolute times I think it's okay, since we want them to correspond to real clock times (at least according to the machine ES is running on), thanks for the explanation!
replies.author: dakrone

timeline.bodyText: Same here about relativeTimeInMillis(), I think we want durations which means relative should work great, rather than absolute where time drift can make things inaccurate
timeline.author: dakrone
dakrone

timeline.bodyText: I'm not that familiar with close listeners, but what happens when the channel has a successful response but the close listener blows up? Should we wrap the listener with a try/catch that logs and ignores exceptions?
timeline.author: dakrone

timeline.bodyText: Can you add a comment here about why we use identityHashCode rather than the regular hash code? (so it doesn't get accidentally removed)
timeline.author: dakrone

replies.bodyText: I'll refactor that into a static method to make it clear what the rationale for identityHashCode there was.
replies.author: danhermann

timeline.bodyText:
These checks should be httpRequest.getHeaders().get("<whatever-header>").size() > 0 rather than a containsKey check, because it's possible for the header list to be an empty list
(I was able to reproduce this with a malicious telnet x 9200 and manually constructing a "bad" HTTP request with an empty User-Agent header)
timeline.author: dakrone

timeline.bodyText: Even though these are marked as volatile, there is still a race condition here because we do a read-then-write that could be from multiple threads. I think instead we should use a LongAdder for both of these
timeline.author: dakrone

timeline.bodyText: If I understand this correctly, we only prune stats once the stats are actually requested. Wouldn't this mean that if the stats are never requested then they can grow unbounded?
timeline.author: dakrone

replies.bodyText: Good point. I'll think about a better way to do that. Probably something based on pruning when new clients connect so that the event that triggers client stats growth is also the one that triggers pruning.
replies.author: danhermann

replies.bodyText: @dakrone, in ea46366, I added a call to pruneClientStats to serverAcceptedChannel so that the same event that triggers client stats growth also triggers pruning. That call is throttled to once per minute to better handle situations where large numbers of client are connecting to a cluster.
replies.author: danhermann

timeline.message: Ensure that client stats cannot grow unbounded

timeline.bodyText: Can you extract this 60 second value and the 5 minute value into private static variables in this class? They're a little easier to discover and change there if we want to tweak them in the future (and it prevents the function call, even if it would end up getting inlined)
timeline.author: dakrone

timeline.bodyText: Can you add a comment and maybe trace logging here, just in case we need it in the future? I don't think we should swallow exceptions without ever making them apparent elsewhere.
timeline.author: dakrone

timeline.bodyText:
Why do we use Strings.EMPTY here? Should we be using jopt stuff here? I think I would prefer to just use either null (and protect when serializing it over transport and xcontent) or "" than pulling in that dependency here.
If we do need the functionality for some reason, maybe we can add it to our own org.elasticsearch.common.Strings class
timeline.author: dakrone

replies.bodyText: Sure, I was thinking of the Strings.EMPTY_ARRAY constant in org.elasticsearch.common.Strings and didn't notice that IntelliJ pulled in the jopt class instead.
replies.author: danhermann

timeline.bodyText: It would probably be easier to make ClientStats implement ToXContentObject than doing the serialization here. It's nicer to encapsulate all the serialization in the class.
timeline.author: dakrone

timeline.bodyText: Should these string fields be protected with if (Strings.hasText(clientStats.opaqueId)) {...} so we don't output fields we don't care about? (or null check if we end up not using Strings.EMPTY)
timeline.author: dakrone

replies.bodyText: I think that makes sense for forwardedFor and opaqueId. An HTTP client will always have a remote address and at least one request URI.
replies.author: danhermann
